issue.title: Percent synced: take into account partial files already transferred

labels.name: frozen-due-to-age
labels.description: Issues closed and untouched for a long time, together with being locked for discussion

issue.body:
Right now, it seems like the "Syncing (x%)" message is calculating the percent of full files that are completely synced.

I attempted to sync a large file (~700 MB), and Syncthing just sat there at "10% synced" ( I already had a ~80 MB file synced before) until the entire file was completely synced, and then Syncthing reported "100% synced".

Can the "Syncing (x%)" be changed to include partial syncs of files in progress?

_Ex: at 1/2 of the large file, show "Syncing (60%)"._

issue.title: Sync percentage is based upon the # of files synced so far? Should be based upon the size synced so far.

labels.name: frozen-due-to-age
labels.description: Issues closed and untouched for a long time, together with being locked for discussion

issue.body:
Hi,

A friend (@reashlin) and I were testing Pulse with a single large file. The percentage indicator remained at 0% while the transfer occurred (for a good 45 mins or so). I guess this is because the % calculation is based upon the number of files synced. Wouldn't it be better to base it upon the number of bytes synced instead? This would offer the user better progress feedback.

We were syncing between OpenBSD and Arch Linux.

Thanks

body: My solution is to track sharedPullerStates during pullerIteration. When changed (updated or closed) they will send message through channel to tracker to make it update the sync progress. I've implemented it and it works fine. The thing left to do is to inform gui about changes (currently only page refresh makes it possible to see the progress of syncing large file). I think about adding new event type but I have doubts if it is efficient enough (sending event every updated block creates many many events). Is the idea to track sharedPullerStates right and how should I make gui update itself (add new event type or make gui update itself every few seconds during syncing phase or something else)?

So my vision was to add a separate go routine to the sharedPullerState which would track the state, and given it's changed, every N seconds would fire off the change via the events interface through to the UI.
It should also carry the information about how many blocks were copied, pulled, etc so that we could have a nice progress bar showing how much of what is coming from where.

Or the other way which I think the way you've done it is even better, as all the pullers share a single channel which they send information through to, and then the tracker sucks on the channel, accumulates the updates and fires them off every N seconds.

Either way, I can look into your implementation and perhaps make suggestions (if any) if you'd like.

Regardless I am really happy somebody has started looking into this. 
Good work.
Here is what I've written: 8a3d84d969671f3c4d73b00c812410ae6f2f55ec. Please, point out what would you like to be done differently, or tell me that it's ok, so I will send a pull request.

So it seems to track the folder as a whole, rather than per file, plus it seems to track only the number of bytes left (oppose to how many bytes have been copied (and from where), how many bytes have been pulled, how many bytes left in total).

I guess I just imagined it differently, showing the overall sync progress as it is now, but then showing progress per individual file being downloaded, perhaps being grouped per repo. Also given we know the progress per file, we could work out the extra % we need to add to the folder completion percentage, to make it less chunky.

I'll go through it in more detail later today.

I focused on showing global progress. I think I can easily add tracking all information you mentioned per file, but I have no idea where to put gathered statistics, and how to present them to the user.
Yeah the UI is the tricky part. I'd be inclined to hack something with 'on hover' in the footer or somewhere.
Have you decided upon something?

So I took your approach, and started iterating on it a bit to make it less intrusive and more detailed.
I don't have access to my repos at the moment, but will drop you a link in the evening.

https://github.com/AudriusButkevicius/syncthing/commit/46206c7341b9008363636635202c9427f93145bc

This is my first basic stab at it.
I am not sure, maybe your publish approach is better than my pull approach, but I somehow felt that 
there might be channel contention at the emitter since every 128kb copied or pulled would have to push something down the progress channel, plus when there is 18 different routines hammering stuff through the channel

Existing two issues my approach is that the `.Register` should be done after the state has been received at the copy channel, because the way it is now it makes it look like there are two downloads in progress, where in reality there is only one, and the other is hanging on the channel to be read.
The other issue it doesn't actually update the progress live, you need to refresh the page, I think it's missing the `refreshFolder` call you are making.

My vision was to extend the `Out of sync` dialog, and add a stacked progress bar stacking from different colours one fo each:
1. Reused blocks from temp file
2. Blocks copied from original file
3. Blocks copied from other random files
4. Blocks pulled
5. Blocks being pulled (pending)

I totally agree with the pull approach, in mine, `sharedPullerStates` published just that they changed, data was also pulled.

I'm not sure though about `ProgressEmitter` working all the time, even when no folder is currently being pulled. Maybe each `pullerIteration` will activate the `ProgressEmitter` if it's not currently working and it will deactivate itself when last `pullerIteration` will finish.

I may be wrong, but I don't like `ProgressEmitter.registry` being a `map[string]*sharedPullerState`. Is `s.folder+s.file.Name` really a unique-per-file-in-folder string? I just imagine something like folder "a" with file "bc" and folder "ab" with file "c". Why isn't it of type `map[string]map[string]*sharedPullerState` like `last`?

Also, I think that `finisherRoutine` doesn't handle `earlyClosed` `sharedPullerStates`, so they might not get deregistered.

Size of file is calculated this way:

```
if f.NumBlocks < 2 {
    return BlockSize / 2
} else {
    return int64(f.NumBlocks-1)*BlockSize + BlockSize/2
}
```

, so I think that just subtracting `int64(m.progressEmitter.BlocksCompleted(folder)*protocol.BlockSize)` in `NeedSize` may be too inaccurate. I don't see a nice way to repair it, but why isn't the size of file simply `int64(f.NumBlocks)*BlockSize`?

About live progress, I just call `refreshFolder`, but I think that the better way would be to just update progress data, not whole folder data.

I like the stacked progress bar idea.

Thank you.

Regarding the emitter working always, I guess when we deregister the last element, we can just do `timer.Stop()`, and when we register the first element, we can just do `timer.Reset(interval)`

You are right, `s.folder+s.file.Name` might not be unique, but `filepath.Join(s.folder, s.file.Name)` is guaranteed to be, as you cannot have two folders with the same name.
The reason I chose a 1 level map is just to avoid the hassle of creating a submap for each folder.
Plus in the future, folders might come and go, so I would either have to do `do I have a submap for this particular folder yet`, or alternatively handle folder changes from the config handler.

Regarding `earlyClose` and file sizes, you are completely right, it's just unfinished work.
It's easy to fix my current mess with blocks, I guess you should just create a new function in protocol package:

```
func BlocksToSize(num int) int64 {
  if num < 2 {
    return BlockSize / 2
  }
  return int64(num-1)*BlockSize + BlockSize/2
}
```

And then replace the calculation in both places with this function call.

The reason the calculation is done this way is because blocks are rounded up to the closest 128kb, so even a 1 byte file counts as 128kb, therefore what this does, is tries to round it down to the closes half... which doesn't help that much, but does help a bit I guess.

Would you be interested in ironing this out in full, and perhaps making a pull request?
If yes, the CSS tweaks required for the progress bar can be found here:
http://jsbin.com/kutudabiwa/1/edit?html,css,output
I guess we can go full blown animated progress bars

If not, let me know, and I'll try to find some time for this myself :+1:
Yes, I'll do it gladly.

I've realized why the timer stop approach will not work.
And it is because as you de-register the last puller, you still need to make one last announcement to clear the progress bars from showing up, hence you cannot stop the timer at that point.

I'm wrapping things up, but I've encountered a problem.
The sync percentage (that one on the right from dir name) sometimes is over 100%. I think what happens is this: let's say file of size 1GB is being synchronized, and 0.5GB is now pulled. Somewhere this file is changed to be 0.2GB. Now our sync % will be calculated like this: 
`(total - left) / total = (total - (size - synced)) / total = (total - (0.2-0.5)) / total > 1`.
It is also possible, that I messed something up. I would be glad if you could check if the idea of decreasing bytes in `model.NeedSize` by `m.progressEmitter.BytesCompleted` is correct.
By the way, that css tweak should be put in overrides.css, right?

Yeah it's not perfect, and I don't think it ever was:
https://github.com/syncthing/syncthing/issues/679

I guess the right answer would be to to leave it as it is for now, 
and revisit it later.

I am planning to implement some sort of `files to pull` queue at some point which will then allow
better estimates.

Yeah the CSS should go into the overrides.

I guess as a temporary workaround you can do:
`min(max(percentage, 0), 100)` in JS.

c9bc8bb5300422624066e1ad6c504dadd4a54bfe

This is what I've changed.

I don't  brutally change percentage to always be between 0 and 100, because I think it's misleading. If you want that workaround, I will put it. However, for I think the same reason, out of sync can also have negative bytes count. I thought about getting better values from `progressemiter`, but it doesn't know about all files currently being synced (until their processing starts).

There is also one more issue:
I'm holding progress stats in app.js, and when DownloadProgress event comes, I update this stats, not replace them. Otherwise, when showing out of sync dialogs, right after finishing, progress bar would revert to showing 0/0. On the other hand, because `progressemiter` doesn't know about all files currently being synced, so when this syncs complete and next begins with same files, progress bars show data from previous sync. So, I don't know, when to delete the stats (always/never both seems bad).
So can you make a pull request so that I could make comments under the lines I would like to comment?

Thanks for implementing this very useful progress information! 
Two little suggestions: 
- for the UI change "Pulled" to "Downloaded" (line 787 in gui/index.html) to keep in line with "folders / devices" instead of "repositories / nodes" - and it's also easier to translate to other languages 
- Are these new per file calculated percentages also reflected on the folder / device percentage? (lines 103 and 246 in gui/index.html)

Request: #999
1. I changed "Pulled" to "Downloaded".
2. They do reflect on folder percentage.

issue.title: Showing detailed sync progress (fixes #476)

labels.name: frozen-due-to-age
labels.description: Issues closed and untouched for a long time, together with being locked for discussion

issue.body: Added `progressEmitter` class to monitor progress and `DownloadProgress` event. Out of sync dialog shows now detailed info about each file progress in a fancy stacked progress bar.
